bibl.title: Letter from Sophia Hawthorne to Elisabeth Peabody.

div1.p: This letter, written by Sophia Hawthorne to her sister Elisabeth Peabody, discusses the death of their nephew Horace Mann, Jr. and the subsequent reaction of his mother (their sister, Mary Tyler Peabody Mann).

Oh Elisabeth, 1 your letter of November 12 came
yesterday noon, after immense longing
on my part to hear from you about
Horace
2 particularly, and now alas the
beloved child has passed into the
heavens. From the delay of the letter,
I had great fears that either Horace
or Mary
3 were very ill, and that you
waited to give me good news. I am
deeply grieved, and notwithstanding
your precaution in preparing the
way to tell me finally that he was
"still forever." I was smitten to the
heart when I came to that; for I
began to think you told me the details
of his illness as the "sad news" and that
he lived yet here below. Fortunately
the blow made me burst into tears
and sobs, (a very rare thing for me now)
so that the acute pang did not hurt me
so much. But I am in the greatest
anxiety about Mary. The world has
lost a rare person. Where will you find
such fidelity, such devotion, such earnestness,
such perseverance, such solemn
dedication of the talents God has given.
I loved him greatly, and my respect
for his life was profound. I mourn
for my dear Horace with deepest
sorrow. I did hope to persuade him
to come to us in Dresden for recreation,
change and observation of the gains
of science here. He was so large in
his scope. When I asked him once
which branch of science he preferred
he looked at me with surprise and replied
"How can I like one branch of science better
than another?" True enough — how can
anyone — and yet, how few have this
broad love, and how many keep in
one groove. His was indeed the genuine
love for the widest knowledge. His
magnificent purposes and hopes
probably needed another sphere to
be fulfilled, for oh Elisabeth, I never
believed that Horace would live to
the prime of manhood in this world.
I was sure he would die young, and
so I am not surprised, however much
I grieve. He had not robustness of
constitution enough to bear such constant
and profound study. He told me once
he was never for one moment rested,
and never expected to be! He worked
with pure spirit always, and not
with physical power. Even his
enormous walks and climbings
and reachings in America and
the Sandwich Islands 4 and everywhere,
were accomplished because his
will and wish were so omnipotent—
not because he had bodily force
enough. It was sublime and
beautiful to a degreehardly
surpassed. I feel honored that I
was related to him. I think there
never was a purer sacrifice offered
to disinterested science. He was a
martyr without stain. When I saw
him first with the seal of death on his
brow (as I know) it was astonishing to
observe the fine beauty of his face—
the intellectual dignity suddenly
increased so much. Julian 5 remarked
yesterday that when he bade him
goodbye on the eve before we left Boston
that he had never seen him look
so well—(meaning so fine in expression)
Ah it is we only who are disappointed!
and lamenting— For just think of him
now with no obstruction between him
and the universe of God. Think how
his face shines with eternal joy as
he apprehends the secrets of creation.
If he had had a stronger body and
tougher health, he would doubtless
have lost in delicacy of perception
and acute sensibility to all the
mysterious laws and results of Nature.
Also in living here among less
exalted persons in his vocation he might have
finally merged spirit in the matter
that is also so wonderful and fine.
He was too susceptible of suffering for
those who loved him vitally, to really
enjoy his progress. I was always in
terror of the sudden breaking down
of overtaxed brain and nerves.
I thank God he did not lose his
reason under the pressure of his cares.
Oh how much better that he should
enter into endless Rest than to
merely exist here without use of reason.
That would surely have broken our hearts.
But he entered the mansion prepared
for him in his Heavenly Father's House, living
and conscious through all his being.
Were not the words he first heard
well done, Thou good and faithful servant. Thou hast
been faithful over a few things. I will
make thee ruler over many things! 6
Enter thou into the joy of thy Lord. 7
For has not he gained five talents
more than the five which the Lord
delivered unto him?
8 Did he ever
fold one in a napkin? When his
mother's first agony of separation is
over, his noble life will come back
to her like an angel of consolation —;
and she will feel rewarded in a
celestial way for her truly divine
care and sympathy with him. One in
a thousand mothers is she, and it
would indeed be a pity to part such
love. It is not parted— oh no —; His
gratitude on earth to her could never
reach his gratitude to her in heaven
where he can better appreciate it and
understand her single devotion to
his highest good. And his father is
there to receive and welcome him
without a misgiving! For did not he
rise to his father's most ardent
prayers for him? I am comforting
myself —; How I wish I could comfort
Mary. God alone can speak to her.
I do not know what it is to lose a son.
God bless and help her, as He surely will.
Her remarkable fortitude will aid her
now, and also her generous tenderness.
I hope she will live for the others.
She said once she wished to live till
Ben 9 was 21. I hope she will not
be drawn up into the blessed land
after Horace, and I think she will
stay for the rest. She has such
identity of life with her children,
that I cannot conceive of their doing
without her on earth. If Horace could
miss any thing 10 in a state, the felicity
of which eye hath not seen nor
ear heard, it would be his mother's
embracing care. But he has that
still, and all else superadded, and
as I first exclaimed with sobs
and tears He never will be tired any
more! Human power could never
compass what he meant to do, and
not to disappoint him, His Heavenly
Father took him from earthly
obstacles and constant suffering,
where he can never more be cold
nor weary nor interrupted in his
immortal course of knowledge
and aspiration. Two witnesses
have George 11 and Ben now
in heaven —; Two angels to watch and
ward. I trust you have written
again to tell me how they do and
how they bear it. But of Mary
I am most fearful, because she
is frail, and had lately been so ill.
She has such strength of endurance that
I believe she will live here as long
as she desires to live, because also
her wish to live is so unselfish.
She wishes to live for her children
and not for herself. Perhaps by and
by I can write to her, but how could
I speak to her now. I am dumb
before her in this terrible moment.

I think with satisfaction of what
is very trifling to others —; but not to
me. It is that Horace was always
very affectionate and sweet to me
I remember his grasp of hand
and his smile whenever I met
him —-; and whenever he said Aunt
Sophia—; was always moved, each
time, as if he first said it then.
I also remember well what a respect
and regard my husband had for
him. He always liked to talk
with him and to hear everything
he said. His sincerity, seriousness
of purpose and varied knowledge
and intelligence made him
so attractive to Mr. Hawthorne —;
and in his presence there was such
a modest dignity of manners —;
so thoughtful an air of
conscientious consideration as
was truly beautiful.
I believe the last time I saw him
in Concord was when he came in
loaded with lovely arethusas —; and
presented me with a radiant
sheaf of them. I was always thankful
to see him come —; but how seldom
he came. I felt he could not waste
his time, for seldom anyone so
impressed me with the value of
moments. He never wasted any
time! What a marvel! Not since
childhood, when he began to try
chemic experiments. How thoroughly
he obeyed the commandWork while
it is day —;

When he came home from the
Sandwich Islands, 4 there was a knot of
pain on his brow, which did not wear
quite away till I saw the seal of
death take its place. I always
wondered what had troubled him.
Perhaps he has now told his mother —;
but I am sure he had some great
trouble which he thought best to
keep to himself. I sometimes
thought I would ask him to tell
me, as he might be reluctant to
disturb his mother —; for I thought
he would feel better to relieve
himself of it, whatever he was.
It is no matter now —-; for when
the golden gate turned back on its
inges, and shut him in from
the world, all cares were left
outside, and his brow now is smooth
with peace. I begin today to be
conscious of his peace —; I could think
of only Mary's loss and the loss of
us all at first. Today I have written
myself into an ecstasy with his gain
and relief and I wish I could know
soon about Mary. No doubt a letter
is on its way to me now. This one
of yours may have been at Thode's
a few days. Do not send any more
to the Bankers. 46 B Bautzner
Strasse is my address. The Postman
is a nice man, and every thing is safe
with him. I suppose the Bankers
cannot send letters about.

I do not incline to write or think
of any thing but Horace and Mary.
You have received four letters from me
before this time —; the three last were
announcements. I will write again
We are all well, and happy to be here.
I should like some money very much. I
was to have some from Ticknor & Fields 12
in November for the former books 13 —; But I hear
the firm is dissolved. If so, perhaps I
am without redress. I wish Mr Hillard 14
could send my January dividend so I
can have it by 1st January. What he
is sure of.he can advance me perhaps.
All send love and deep sympathy. We are at
housekeeping since 19th November and taking German lessons. Goodbye

p.add:
Do not write the A in my name, because I write it here Sophia Hawthorne
only. Rose 15 wrote to you last week.
PS. The postage is 10 cents to Dresden
